CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant and ORG , may be summarised as follows . Some of the facts are in dispute between the parties .

CARDINAL . On DATE , a number of factual questions were put to ORG Rule CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a ) ) , which concerned the applicant ’s situation in GPE before her arrival in the GPE . ORG submitted their replies on DATE and the applicant ’s comments in reply were submitted on DATE .

CARDINAL . The relevant instruments and principles under ORG law have been set out in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of ORG v. GPE and GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , ECHR DATE ) , in particular :
Council Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , laying down minimum standards for the reception of asylum seekers in the Member States ( “ the Reception Directive ” ) ;

ORG ( ORG ) no . CARDINAL of DATE , establishing the criteria and mechanisms for determining the Member State of ORG responsible for examining an asylum application lodged in one of GPE by a third - country national ( “ the Dublin II Regulation ” ) ;

Council Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EC of DATE , on minimum standards for the qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as refugees or as persons who otherwise need international protection and the content of the protection granted : ( “ the LAW ” ) ; and
Council Directive CARDINAL of DATE on minimum standards on procedures in Member GPE for granting and withdrawing refugee status in the Member GPE ( “ the Procedures Directive ” ) .

CARDINAL . Under the Dublin II Regulation , GPE must determine , based on a hierarchy of objective criteria ( Articles CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) , which Member ORG bears responsibility for examining an asylum application lodged on their territory . The aim is to avoid multiple applications and to guarantee that each asylum seeker ’s case is dealt with by a single Member ORG . Where it is established that an asylum seeker has irregularly crossed the border into a Member ORG having come from a third country , the Member ORG thus entered is responsible for examining the asylum application ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Where the criteria in the regulation indicate that another Member ORG is responsible , that ORG is requested to take charge of the asylum seeker and examine the application for asylum ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In its ruling of DATE in the cases of ORG v. Secretary of ORG for ORG and PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON ORG Commissioner , Minister for Justice , LAW , ORG and ORG , ORG of ORG of ORG considered in respect of transfers under the terms of the Dublin II Regulation that although ORG is based on mutual trust and the presumption of compliance by other Member GPE law and fundamental rights in particular , such a presumption is rebuttable . In this ruling , it held inter alia :

“ DATE . Consideration of the texts which constitute ORG shows that it was conceived in a context making it possible to assume that all the participating GPE , whether Member LAW or GPE , observe fundamental rights , including the rights based on LAW and LAW , and on LAW , and that the Member GPE can have confidence in each other in that regard . ...
CARDINAL . In those circumstances , it must be assumed that the treatment of asylum seekers in all Member GPE complies with the requirements of the LAW , LAW and the ORG .

CARDINAL . It is not however inconceivable that that system may , in practice , experience major operational problems in a given Member ORG , meaning that there is a substantial risk that asylum seekers may , when transferred to that Member ORG , be treated in a manner incompatible with their fundamental rights .

CARDINAL . Nevertheless , it can not be concluded from the above that any infringement of a fundamental right by the Member ORG responsible will affect the obligations of the other Member GPE to comply with the provisions of Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . At issue here is the raison d’être of ORG and the creation of an area of freedom , security and justice and , in particular , ORG , based on mutual confidence and a presumption of compliance , by other Member GPE , with ORG law and , in particular , fundamental rights .

CARDINAL . In addition , it would be not be compatible with the aims of Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL were the slightest infringement of Directives CARDINAL , CARDINAL or CARDINAL/CARDINAL to be sufficient to prevent the transfer of an asylum seeker to the Member ORG primarily responsible . Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL aims – on the assumption that the fundamental rights of the asylum seeker are observed in the Member ORG primarily responsible for examining the application – to establish ... a clear and effective method for dealing with an asylum application . In order to achieve that objective , Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL provides that responsibility for examining an asylum application lodged in a ORG country rests with a single Member ORG , which is determined on the basis of objective criteria .

CARDINAL . If the mandatory consequence of any infringement of the individual provisions of Directives CARDINAL , CARDINAL or CARDINAL/CARDINAL by the Member ORG responsible were that the Member ORG in which the asylum application was lodged is precluded from transferring the applicant to the first mentioned ORG , that would add to the criteria for determining the Member ORG responsible set out in LAW No CARDINAL/CARDINAL another exclusionary criterion according to which minor infringements of the abovementioned directives committed in a certain Member ORG may exempt that Member ORG from the obligations provided for under Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL . Such a result would deprive those obligations of their substance and endanger the realisation of the objective of quickly designating the Member ORG responsible for examining an asylum claim lodged in ORG .

CARDINAL . By contrast , if there are substantial grounds for believing that there are systemic flaws in the asylum procedure and reception conditions for asylum applicants in the Member ORG responsible , resulting in inhuman or degrading treatment , within the meaning of LAW [ of LAW of ORG ] , of asylum seekers transferred to the territory of that Member ORG , the transfer would be incompatible with that provision . ...

CARDINAL . NORP ... , the presumption underlying the relevant legislation , stated in paragraph CARDINAL above , that asylum seekers will be treated in a way which complies with fundamental rights , must be regarded as rebuttable .

CARDINAL . In the light of those factors , ... ORG law precludes the application of a conclusive presumption that the Member ORG which LAW No CARDINAL/CARDINAL indicates as responsible observes the fundamental rights of ORG .

CARDINAL . DATE of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of ORG must be interpreted as meaning that GPE , including the national courts , may not transfer an asylum seeker to the ‘ Member State responsible’ within the meaning of Regulation No CARDINAL/CARDINAL where they can not be unaware that systemic deficiencies in the asylum procedure and in the reception conditions of asylum seekers in that Member ORG amount to substantial grounds for believing that the asylum seeker would face a real risk of being subjected to inhuman or degrading treatment within the meaning of that provision . ”
CARDINAL . The domestic law and practice as regards asylum proceedings and enforcement of removals are set out in PERSON the GPE ( ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE and § § DATE , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . As regards transfers to GPE under LAW , the GPE authorities decide in consultation with the NORP authorities how and when the transfer of an asylum seeker to the competent NORP authorities will take place . In principle CARDINAL working days’ notice is given , in accordance with article LAW ( ORG ) No . DATE . Requests by the NORP authorities for a longer period of notice are respected .

CARDINAL . If the transfer involves a vulnerable person , such as an unaccompanied alien minor or an unaccompanied mother with small children , the GPE authorities will explicitly bring this to the attention of the NORP authorities and give the latter CARDINAL days’ notice . The same period of notice is in principle given where a transfer involves exceptional medical circumstances . If a doctor sets conditions for a transfer , such as the presence of a wheelchair , a doctor or an ambulance for the asylum seeker ’s transport to a hospital or other institution , arrangements are made with the NORP authorities prior to the transfer in order to fulfil this condition . Only after confirmation has been received that the condition will be met , will the transfer be actually carried out .

CARDINAL . Unlike unaccompanied minor asylum seekers , families are in principle not escorted . They are considered capable on their arrival at the airport of reporting on their own initiative to the NORP authorities who – having received notice DATE are aware of the family ’s impending arrival . An escort may be provided if the parent or parents are unable to look after the children themselves . ORG ( ORG ) , who carry out the actual transfer and are present in person at the airport to turn the family over to the NORP authorities , are responsible for deciding whether an escort is needed . Whenever a transfer takes place , the person in question is informed that he or she should report to the border police ( polizia di frontiera ) at the airport .

CARDINAL . A person wishing to apply for asylum in GPE should do so with the border police or , if already in GPE , with the police ( questura ) immigration department . As soon as an asylum request has been filed , the petitioner is granted access to GPE as well as to the asylum procedure , and is authorised to remain in GPE pending the determination of the asylum request by ORG for ORG .

CARDINAL . For petitioners who do not hold a valid entry visa , an identification procedure ( fotosegnalamento ) is carried out by the police – if need be – with the assistance of an interpreter . This procedure comprises the taking of passport photographs and fingerprints . The fingerprints are checked for matches in ORG and the domestic ORG ( Automated Fingerprint Identification System ) database . At DATE procedure , the petitioner is given a notice confirming the first registration ( cedolino ) , on which future appointments are noted , in particular the appointment for the formal registration of the request .

CARDINAL . The formal asylum request will be made in writing . On the basis of an interview held with the petitioner in a language which he or she understands , the police will fill out the “ Standard form C/CARDINAL for the recognition of refugee status according to LAW ” ( ORG C/CARDINAL per il riconoscimento dello status di rifugiato ai sensi della PERSON di PERSON ) , which contains questions on the petitioner ’s personal data ( name , surname , date of birth , citizenship , name and surname of parents / spouse / children and their whereabouts ) as well as the details of the journey to GPE and reasons for fleeing the country of origin and for seeking asylum in GPE . The petitioner will be asked to provide a written paper , which will be appended to the form , containing his or her asylum account and written in his or her own language . The police will retain the original form and provide the petitioner with a stamped copy .

CARDINAL . The petitioner will then be invited by a notification served in writing by the police for a hearing before the competent ORG for ORG . During this hearing , the petitioner will be assisted by an interpreter . ORG can :
- grant asylum by recognising the petitioner as a refugee within the meaning of the DATE LAW relating to ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ” ) ;

- not recognise the petitioner as a refugee under LAW but grant subsidiary protection under the terms of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) as implemented by LAW ( decreto legislativo ) no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ;
- not grant asylum or subsidiary protection but grant a residence permit for compelling humanitarian reasons under the terms of LAW ( decreto legge ) nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and GPE ; or
- not grant the petitioner any form of protection . In this case the petitioner will be provided with an order to leave GPE ( foglio di via ) within DATE .

CARDINAL . A person recognised as refugee under LAW will be provided with a renewable residence permit with a validity of DATE . He or she is further entitled , inter alia , to a travel document for aliens ( Titolo di viaggio per stranieri ) , to work , to family reunion and to benefit from the general schemes for social assistance , health care , social housing and education under NORP domestic law .

CARDINAL . A person granted subsidiary protection will be provided with a residence permit with a validity of DATE which can be renewed by ORG that granted it . This permit can further be converted into a residence permit for the purposes of work in GPE , provided this is requested before the expiry of the validity of the residence permit and provided the person concerned holds an identity document . A residence permit granted for subsidiary protection entitles the person concerned , inter alia , to a travel document for aliens , to work , to family reunion and to benefit from the general schemes for social assistance , health care , social housing and education under NORP domestic law .

CARDINAL . A person granted a residence permit for compelling humanitarian reasons will be provided with a residence permit with a validity of DATE which can be converted into a residence permit for the purposes of work in GPE , provided the person concerned holds a passport . A residence permit granted on humanitarian grounds entitles the person concerned to work , to health care and , in case he or she has no passport , to a travel document for aliens .

CARDINAL . An appeal against a decision by ORG not to grant international protection can be lodged with the civil law tribunal ( sezione civile del Tribunale ) and further appeals can be filed with ORG ( Corte di appello ) and , in last instance , ORG ( Corte di cassazione ) . Such appeals must be presented by a lawyer and the asylum seeker concerned can apply for legal aid for this purpose .

CARDINAL . An asylum seeker can withdraw his or her asylum request at any stage of the proceedings on the determination of that request by completing a form to that effect . This form can be obtained at the police immigration department . A formal withdrawal entails the end of the proceedings without a determination of the asylum request by ORG . However , there is no automatic assumption of withdrawal of an asylum request when the petitioner has left the asylum ORG reception centre , has left for an unknown destination or has left the country . In case a petitioner fails to appear before ORG , it will formally indicate his or her absence and determine the request on the basis of the contents of the case file . In most cases , it will reject the asylum request for “ untraceability ” ( diniego per irreperibilità ) . In such a situation , the person concerned can request a fresh hearing and the procedure is reactivated when a date for a fresh interview has been communicated to him or her .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW no . PERSON , implementing ORG of DATE on laying down minimum standards for the reception of asylum seekers , asylum seekers in GPE are entitled to reception facilities . According to article LAW , reception arrangements are to be made on the basis of the specific needs of asylum seekers and their families , in particular the needs of vulnerable persons , i.e. unaccompanied minors , disabled persons , pregnant women , single parents with minor children , and persons who have been subjected to torture , rape or other forms of serious psychological , physical or sexual violence . NORP domestic law provides for special guarantees for such vulnerable persons , including a reserved quota of places in the ORG ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) reception scheme .

CARDINAL . In the “ ORG on important aspects of refugee protection in GPE ” of DATE by the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees ( ORG ) , the arrangements for reception of asylum seekers in GPE is described as follows :

“ Legislative Decree No . PERSON ... is the main law underpinning the NORP reception system . The decree foresees that those who apply for protection in GPE , but lack the means to ensure a dignified standard of living for themselves , are , in principle , hosted in adequate reception facilities . The reception system currently includes the following types of facilities : ORG for ORG ( ORG ) , ORG for migrants ( ORG ) , local projects established in the context of ORG ) and centres in so - called ‘ metropolitan ORG , which have been set up in large cities . The system has recently been complemented by an emergency reception plan managed by ORG which was rolled out to address migratory flows from GPE from DATE .

Based on a series of requirements set out in LAW . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , some asylum - seekers who arrive in GPE are initially referred to CARAs , mainly for identification purposes . CARAs are open facilities which are run by organisations selected through a public tender procedure managed by the local Prefecture . The QUANTITY CARAs which are currently operational in various NORP regions have a total capacity of CARDINAL places . At times , however , reception facilities for migrants , or CDAs , are also used to host asylum - seekers , bringing the total capacity in GPE to CARDINAL regular places . Asylum - seekers falling into specific categories ( namely those previously served with an expulsion order ) may also be detained in ORG ( ORG ) .

The ORG network of reception and integration projects , whose members include municipalities , provinces and non - profit organisations , is coordinated by ORG and currently managed by ORG ( ORG ) . Funding is provided through a public tender procedure managed by ORG . ORG ’s CARDINAL projects have a total capacity for CARDINAL persons . CARDINAL places are set aside for vulnerable individuals , including CARDINAL for individuals suffering from serious mental disorders . ORG projects host beneficiaries of international protection and of national humanitarian protection as well as asylum - seekers . With regard to asylum - seekers , places in the ORG network are usually for vulnerable or destitute asylum - seekers whose identification procedures have been completed or who have spent DATE in a ORG .

In DATE , due to the limited capacity of the ORG network , asylum - seekers who could have been hosted in this type of reception facility have often been referred to CARAs . Asylum - seekers who would , according to the policy , have spent a maximum of DATE in a ORG have therefore stayed on in these facilities until their asylum procedures were completed , or , in some cases , DATE , without being able to access ORG projects . As regards the length of their stay , asylum - seekers hosted in ORG projects may , in a number of given circumstances , extend their stay for DATE after they are granted a form of international protection .

In general terms , those hosted in CARAs should benefit from a series of services beyond food and accommodation , which include health care and mental health care , training and recreational activities , and legal assistance . The relevant legal framework defines common minimum standards for CARAs at the national level , which are now included in all contracts for the management of these reception facilities . Services in ORG reception facilities are less homogeneous and accommodation is generally foreseen in small to medium - sized facilities such as flats where services are geared towards facilitating local integration .

In DATE , following a significant number of arrivals from GPE and the ensuing declaration of a state of ‘ humanitarian emergency’ , regional governments were asked to identify additional reception facilities , given that the existing reception capacity was deemed to be insufficient . An agreement was then reached between the central Government and the relevant local authorities ( regions , provinces governed by a special statute and municipalities ) , setting out criteria for the distribution of CARDINAL persons across the country , with regional quotas based on population size . Responsibility for the management of this ‘ Migrant Reception Plan’ was assigned to the Head of ORG , who was designated Emergency Administrator . As of DATE , over CARDINAL forced migrants have been hosted in the framework of the plan , mostly in small to medium - sized facilities spread out throughout GPE ( with the exception of the GPE region ) .

ORG expresses its appreciation for the improvements to the reception system which have been carried out in DATE . Overall , the CARAs , CDAs and ORG projects are able to provide for the reception needs of a significant number of asylum - seekers . However , ORG believes that a number of issues continue to be of concern , namely the following : i ) when significant numbers of arrivals take place , CDAs , CARAs and ORG projects alone are unable to host all asylum - seekers who can not provide for themselves ; ii ) the actual level of assistance and the quality of services provided vary significantly depending on the type of facility , with ORG projects offering reception in a multitude of small facilities , many of which have established strong ties to the local area , whilst CARAs and CDAs are larger facilities with capacities ranging from a minimum of CARDINAL places to a maximum of CARDINAL places ; ( iii ) the criteria and procedures for referring individual asylum - seekers to a ORG or a ORG project are not always set out formally in writing ; ( iv ) there have been a number of instances in which reception in a ORG was limited to a maximum of DATE , a practice which does not appear to be in line with the ORG Directive on reception conditions , when applied to asylum - seekers who are unable to provide for themselves and have not received a decision on their applications within this period ; however , recently , ORG has received assurances from ORG that this restrictive practice will be discontinued ; ( v ) CARAs do not all offer the same reception services , with the quality of assistance varying between facilities and sometimes failing to meet adequate standards , especially regarding the provision of legal and psycho - social assistance ; According to the “ Dublin II Regulation National Report ” on GPE , published in DATE by the NORP network for technical cooperation on the application of the Dublin II Regulation ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , ORG ( ORG für ORG ) has appealed all of the few judgments which obliged it to invoke the sovereignty clause by taking over responsibility for an asylum request from the country of first abode and , so far , the NORP constitutional court has not suspended any transfer to GPE .

CARDINAL . In its ruling no . CARDINAL given on DATE , concerning the complaint that the transfer from GPE to GPE of an NORP asylum seeker would breach the latter ’s rights under LAW , the Acting President of Chamber IV of ORG ( Conseil du contentieux des étrangers / PERSON vreemdelingen - betwistingen ) decided to suspend the removal order issued against the appellant . After having extensively cited the relevant principles in the ORG ’s case - law under the ORG , it held :

“ QUANTITY . ... The general information added to the file by the applicant shows – at this stage of the proceedings – to a sufficient degree that currently there are serious problems in GPE as regards the manner in which asylum seekers are being treated . Although press reports and/or general reports do not in itself suffice for finding a violation of LAW , it appears in the instant case that the [ NORP Deputy Minister for Asylum and Migration ] , in taking her decision in which she refers to the responsibility of GPE as to the processing of the asylum request , has not sufficiently taken into account the precarious situation of asylum seekers since the events in GPE .

The appellant further correctly points out that , since the NORP authorities failed to reply to the transfer request , there is no formal approval by the NORP authorities from which it could ( implicitly ) be derived that he will be given suitable reception .

It follows that the applicant seems to have an arguable claim based on LAW . The grounds for appeal , in so far as they allege a violation of LAW , thus appear to be serious at this stage of the proceedings . ”

CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG and GPE examined – in the case of EM ( GPE ) and others v. the Secretary of ORG for ORG [ DATE ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL –whether the return of any of the CARDINAL appellants to GPE , either as an asylum - seeker or as a person already accepted as a refugee there , would entail a real risk of inhuman or degrading treatment in violation of LAW . The appellants claimed that GPE ’s system for the reception and settlement of asylum - seekers and refugees is in large part dysfunctional , with the result that anyone arriving or returned there , even if they have children with them , faces a very real risk of destitution .

CARDINAL . ORG considered this question in the light of the materials adduced by the parties , including “ Recommendations on Important Aspects of Refugee Protection in Italy ” as published in DATE by the ORG ; a report of PERSON , ORG Commissioner for Human Rights , issued in DATE following a formal visit to GPE in DATE ; reports from ORG ( deriving from a joint NORP and NORP NGO visit to GPE in DATE ) , from ORG ( a NORP NGO , based on the same visit in DATE ) , from ORG ( a NORP NGO which visited GPE at about the same time ) , from ORG ( in a report entitled ORG , sponsored by the ORG and ORG , updated to DATE ) , from a specialist lawyer , PERSON ( DATE ) , and from CARDINAL other specialist lawyers , PERSON and PERSON ( Critical Aspects of ORG in GPE , DATE ) . It summarised the parties’ position as follows :

“ CARDINAL . The Home Secretary has put a substantial body of evidence before the court describing GPE ’s system for the processing , reception , accommodation and support of asylum - seekers and refugees . We will come in due course to the legal materiality both of this evidence and of the countervailing evidence of the CARDINAL claimants which is summarised above . In essence , as set out in the NORP government ’s ORG exhibited to the witness statement made in [ CARDINAL of the CARDINAL cases ] by [ ... ] , ORG NORP liaison officer , it is as follows .

CARDINAL . Asylum seekers are accommodated in a reception centre for long enough for ORG to evaluate their claims . If accepted as refugees , or while awaiting a decision , they are given an international protection order and assigned to a ‘ territorial project’ which forms part of ORG , the national system for the protection of asylum - seekers and refugees . ORG will either provide accommodation or transfer the claimant to a public or private local provider . Access to ORG is by referral only . It provides food and lodging and courses designed to assist integration , but ( with few exceptions ) the limit of stay there is DATE . On leaving , claimants can apply to charitable or voluntary providers but there is no guarantee of success . However , the international protection order affords access to free healthcare and social assistance ( which does not extend to social security ) equivalent to that enjoyed by nationals . This requires a fiscal code number , which in turn depends on having an address which can be verified by the police . An international protection order also allows the holder to take employment or undertake self - employment , to marry , to apply for family reunification , to obtain education , to seek recognition of foreign qualifications , to apply for public housing and , after DATE , for naturalisation . For those denied these rights , there is , says [ the representative of the ORG Secretary ] , access to the NORP courts .

CARDINAL . The PERSON case is that this may be the system in theory , but their own experience and that of many others , to which independent reports attest , is that it is not what happens in reality to a very considerable number both of asylum - seekers and of recognised refugees . In short , they say , GPE ’s system for the reception and settlement of asylum - seekers and refugees is in large part dysfunctional , with the result that anyone arriving or returned there , even if they have children with them , faces a very real risk of destitution . ”
CARDINAL . Although acknowledging that the NGO reports before it gave a great deal of support to the accounts given by CARDINAL of the appellants of their own experiences in GPE , ORG found :

“ CARDINAL . ... The decision of ORG of ORG in GPE v GPE has set a threshold in GPE II and cognate return cases which exists nowhere else in refugee law . It requires the claimant to establish that there are in the country of first arrival ‘ systemic deficiencies in the asylum procedure and in the reception conditions of asylum seekers ... [ which ] amount to substantial grounds for believing that the asylum seeker would face a real risk of being subjected to inhuman or degrading treatment ... ’ .

CARDINAL . In other words , the sole ground on which a second state is required to exercise its power under article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) Regulation CARDINAL/CARDINAL to entertain a re - application for asylum or humanitarian protection , and to refrain from returning the applicant to the state of first arrival , is that the source of risk to the applicant is a systemic deficiency , known to the former , in the latter ’s asylum or reception procedures . Short of this , even powerful evidence of individual risk is of no avail .

CARDINAL . The totality of the evidence about GPE , although it is extremely troubling and far from uncritical , does not in our judgment come up to this mark . While undoubtedly at a number of points it either overtly alleges or powerfully suggests systemic failure , it is neither unanimously nor compellingly directed to such a conclusion . At least equal , if not greater , weight has to be accorded to the far more sanguine – and more recent - ORG report , echoed as it is , albeit more faintly , by the PERSON report . While what amounts to a systemic deficiency must to a considerable degree be a matter of judgment , perhaps even of vocabulary , the evidence does not demonstrate that GPE ’s system for the reception of asylum seekers and refugees , despite its many shortcomings and casualties , is itself dysfunctional or deficient . This is so whether one focuses on the body of available reports on GPE or the comparative findings in GPE about GPE .

CARDINAL . It has to follow that the CARDINAL claims before the court , despite their supporting testimony of individual risk , are incapable of succeeding CARDINAL on the present evidence , and that the ORG Secretary is therefore justified in that respect in certifying them . ”
